verses.text: Come, bless the LORD, all you servants of the LORD, who stand by night in the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: This psalm opens by calling those ministering in the temple at night to worship God. The original term 'servants' here often referred to priests and Levites serving in the temple, which foreshadows the perpetuity of priestly ministry and continual worship, reminiscent of the perpetual offering in the sanctuary. The emphasis on priesthood and night devotion subtly points to the importance of liturgical prayer, tradition, and the intercession offered by dedicated ministers. Christologically, it hints at Christ as the true eternal high priest who intercedes for humanity (see Heb. 7:24-25).

verses.text: Lift up your hands in the holy place and bless the LORD.
verses.comment: This verse commands the lifting of hands in the sanctuary, a gesture of worship and blessing. The physical expression of prayer signifies a surrender and a reaching out towards God, which has deep roots in both old covenant worship and early Christian liturgy. Interestingly, the strong biblical tradition of bodily worship continues in the form of liturgical gestures, showing the unity of spiritual and physical devotion (see 1 Cor. 11:1). The focus on 'the holy place' underscores the centrality of sacred space and set-apart worship, alluding to the sanctity and continuity of ordered worship throughout salvation history.

verses.text: May the LORD bless you from Zion, He who made heaven and earth.
verses.comment: The psalm concludes with a priestly benediction, invoking blessing from Zion—the place of God's dwelling and the spiritual center of worship. The reference to the Creator highlights the Lord's universal majesty and authority. Spiritually, Zion becomes the figure of God's ultimate dwelling among His people, fulfilled in the new covenant community. The reciprocal relationship—servants bless God, and God blesses them—is central to biblical theology, echoing the continual exchange of blessing in worship that reaches its fullness in Christ, our true mediator (1 Tim. 2:5).
